oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A pictorial key to differentiate the recently detected exotic Haemaphysalis longicornis Neumann, 1901 (Acari, Ixodidae) from native congeners in North America
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Egizi, Andrea
Robbins, Richard G.
Beati, Lorenza
Nava, Santiago
Evans, Colleen R.
Occi, James L.
Fonseca, Dina M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: dichotomous key
invasive species
Haemaphysalis
invasion biology
Haemaphysalis longicornis
native congener
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Until recently, only two haemaphysaline species, <jats:italic>Haemaphysalischordeilis</jats:italic> (Packard, 1869) and <jats:italic>Haemaphysalisleporispalustris</jats:italic> (Packard, 1869), were known to occur in the United States, and neither was considered to be of significant medical or veterinary importance. In 2017â€“2018 established populations of the Asian longhorned tick, <jats:italic>Haemaphysalislongicornis</jats:italic> Neumann, 1901, were detected in the eastern US for the first time. <jats:italic>Haemaphysalislongicornis</jats:italic> has the potential to be a significant threat to human and animal health, and the urgent need to determine the full extent of its distribution and host range requires availability of a straightforward and practical guide to differentiate it from native species. We created a pictorial dichotomous key to all stages of <jats:italic>Haemaphysalis</jats:italic> spp. known to occur in North America with scanning electron photomicrographs of all <jats:italic>H.longicornis</jats:italic> life stages, including rarely seen males, to aid researchers in differentiating these species. The largely Neotropical species <jats:italic>Haemaphysalisjuxtakochi</jats:italic> Cooley, 1946, with established populations in Mexico and sporadic detections in the US on migrating birds is also included.</jats:p>
